NANYANG UNIVERSITY GRADUATES
(Recruitment into Government services and Government and Government-aided secondary schools)


    1. Mr Lin You Eng asked the Minister for Education in 1962 (a) how many Nanyang University graduates were recruited (i) into the Government services and (ii) to teach in Government and Government-aided secondary schools; and (b) how many graduates were rejected in each case.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I suggest to the Member for Moulmein that the first part of his question "how many Nanyang University graduates were recruited into Government services in 1962" should be addressed to my colleague, the Minister for Finance, who will, I am sure, be pleased to supply the answers when the question is put to him?

    As for Nanyang University graduates appointed to teach in Government and Government-aided secondary schools in 1962, the answer is 98. The breakdown is as follows: 



  Government secondary schools		  26



  Government-aided secondary schools      72


    The number not selected for teaching appointments in 1962 was 62. However, 53 others who were considered suitable for teaching appointments were put on the reserve list for 1962 pending vacancies. Of these, 29 have since been appointed to fill vacancies in 1963.

(Recruitment into Government services and Government and Government-aided secondary schools)


    2. Mr Lin You Eng asked the Minister for Education in 1962 (a) how many University of Singapore graduates were recruited (i) into the Government services and (ii) to teach in Government and Government-aided secondary schools; and (b) how many graduates were rejected in each case.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: As in the previous question, may I request the Member for Moulmein for the second time to direct the first part of his question to my colleague, the Minister for Finance, if he desires information regarding the number of University of Singapore graduates recruited into Government services in 1962?

    As regards the number of University of Singapore graduates appointed to teach in Government and Government-aided secondary schools in 1962, the answer is 44. The breakdown is as follows: 



  Government secondary schools 		   28



  Government-aided secondary schools	   16


    No University of Singapore graduate desiring to teach has had his application rejected because the number of applications is less than the number required for ideal staffing in English medium secondary schools.

DISRUPTION OF TRADE UNIONS; REGISTRATION OF
S.A.T.U.; AND FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS OF WORKERS


2.42 p.m.

    Order read for resumption of motion [25th July, 1963],

    `That this Assembly condemns the People's Action Party Government for its use of State machinery against workers and their organisations in an attempt to disrupt non-P.A.P. trade unions and thereby further P.A.P. interests: and demands that this abuse of State power he forthwith stopped, that the Singapore Association of Trade Unions he given immediate registration and that the fundamental rights of association, assembly and publication of all workers he recognised and respected by the Government.'-(Mr S. T. Bani).

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, this Government has shown complete disregard of the principles and ethics of trade unionism. It has abused State power in an unprecedented manner.

    Sir, we have seen how in the case of the Singapore Harbour Board dispute the whole State machinery was used ruthlessly and in full force regardless of ethics and principles in industrial relations. Sir, because of the control over the Press and other media of propaganda, confusion has been brought about as to the basic issues involved in the dispute of the Harbour Board workers,

Column: 202

and also a deliberate distortion of facts has taken place.

    Sir, the Singapore Harbour Board workers have been subjected to all sorts of victimisation for quite some time now. They have been subjected to victimisation since the days of the previous Government. Today, the Singapore People's Alliance led by the Member for Cairnhill comes out championing the cause of the Harbour Board workers. I notice the Member for Cairnhill wishes to raise the dispute of the Port workers in an adjournment motion. Sir, I would like to say here that he and his Government have not been any more tolerant or sympathetic to the water-front workers. The Lim Yew Hock Government encouraged union rivalry, sponsored yellow unions and victimised generally the Harbour Board workers because they rejected the anti-labour policies of his Government. It will be remembered how his Government had refused recognition of the union and had withdrawn the citizenship certificate of the Secretary-General. Therefore, I suggest that today if the Member for Cairnhill comes out and support the cause of the Harbour Board workers, it is because elections are around the corner and he has some vested interests in going to Tanjong Pagar as we can see from the newspapers.

    Sir, to understand the dispute of the Harbour Board workers in the proper perspective, it is necessary to go back a little to trace the source of dispute. In 1957 -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I trust the hon. Member is not exciting a debate on the Harbour Board dispute as a dispute, because the motion is in general terms. It does not refer specifically to the Harbour Board dispute. It can be mentioned, of course, in passing. But we are not debating at the moment the Harbour Board dispute.

    Mr Bani: Sir, I wish to touch on the Harbour Board dispute merely to show how and to what extent the present Government is using State machinery to disrupt unions which reject political control by the Government. Before I could touch on the actual acts indulged in by the present Government in the recent Harbour Board dispute, acts which show

Column: 203

conclusively that the motivation is political, I think it is necessary to understand briefly the problems that the Harbour Board Union is concerned with.

    We submit that the Government has been completely unprincipled in its handling of the Harbour Board dispute. Today, the Harbour Board Staff Association registration has been cancelled. The Prime Minister has unilaterally appointed a committee on behalf of the Harbour Board workers. All this has been done in the name of solving the dispute of the Harbour Board workers. But we say this is just a cover, and the Government act in the Harbour Board only confirms our contention that the Government has consistently been using State machinery to break trade unions and trade union unity in the sector where the P.A.P. has no influence.

    Sir, if I may just briefly say this. In 1957 a Court of Inquiry was appointed by the previous Government which made certain recommendations to be accepted by both disputing parties - the Board and the workers. The present Prime Minister was the legal adviser to the Union then and he presented the case on behalf of the Harbour Board workers. But since the recommendations were published, they have never been implemented. After the elections in 1959, there was a general expectation that these recommendations would be implemented, but the major recommendations up till now have not been implemented. Ever since 1959 after the elections, the Government attitude to the Harbour Board Staff Association has been governed by political considerations. The P.A.P. Government sought to make the Harbour Board Staff Association a tool of the Government. It was decided that if they could not get control of the Harbour Board Staff Association, it would discredit and disrupt the organisation. Sir, in the minds of the P.A.P., it was a very clear decision. Either the Harbour Board Staff Association had to be a P.A.P. organisation or it had to be broken.

    All attempts since 1959 to control the Union failed. Then, having failed in this, the force of State machinery was introduced. Leaders of the Union were prosecuted and smeared. Following the

Column: 204

court case, the Secretary-General of the Union, Mr Jamit Singh, and the Vice-President, Mr Chok Koh Thong, were detained under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance. Immediately following this, yet another attempt was made to capture the Union. In the process of it, the State machinery as usual was used. The C.I.D. called up Committee members, questioned them and threatened them. The Registrar of Trade Unions meddled and interfered with the affairs of the Union. But unfortunately for, the Government, Sir, these attempts again failed. In March, the State machinery was used to a greater extent. On instructions from the Prime Minister, the Harbour Board management withdrew recognition of the Executive Committee of the Union on the grounds that there were two Committees.

    Sir, I wish to explain this myth of two Committees because a certain amount of confusion has arisen because of Government propaganda. The position in March in the Harbour Board Staff Association was that there was only one Executive Council led by Mr S. Markandu, and that had been the position since November 1961. In November 1961, there were elections in the Union. The Executive Council led by Markandu was elected. A member had taken a case out and the High Court is to determine whether these elections were in accordance with the constitution of the Union. Sir, my understanding of the legal position is until such time as the High Court decides that the elections conducted in November were not in accordance with the constitution of the Union, the Committee that had been elected was the rightful authority in the Union. The Harbour Board management had recognised this position and had entered into industrial relations from November last until March this year. But in March, when the Government had failed in all its endeavours to capture the Union, it gave instructions to the Harbour Board management to withdraw recognition of the Union and seize the Union premises. The Government instructed the Registrar of Trade Unions to freeze the funds of the Union, amounting to $120,000. This was a very blatant abuse of State power. Following this, further attempts

Column: 205

were made but they could not deceive the workers, and the resistance to Government control remains.

    Then, Sir, the Prime Minister called officials of the new Committee to his office. Perhaps one reading the newspapers would have felt that it was the officials of the Union who were going to see the Prime Minister. The fact is that the Prime Minister sits in his office; he decides he wants to have Mr Markandu and company and someone else on the old Committee to come to his office; and all he does is to phone up the Harbour Board management and tell them to put these officials in the car and bring them safely to the Prime Minister's Office. Sir, it is not an exaggeration to say that these officials had to be manhandled in order that they could be brought to the Prime Minister's Office, to have their pictures taken by television cameramen, Press cameramen and so on, to give the impression that the Prime Minister was neutral and impartial, trying to solve the dispute by getting two rival groups together. There were no two rival groups. There was only one group. The other group was a group being instigated by the P.A.P. to put up some rivalry. But the legal status, as I have said, was such that there was only one committee. However, in the process of all these so-called conferences in the Prime Minister's Office, the P.A.P. Government succeeded, to some extent, in giving the public the impression that there were two Committees in the Harbour Board, that there was rivalry, and that therefore the Government was justified in asking the Harbour Board to withdraw recognition of the Union, to take away the Union's funds, to take away the Union's premises. It all suited the Government's machinations, Mr Speaker, because what the Government wanted was to set up a Committee of stooges in the Harbour Board; and if they could play up this myth that there were these two Committees fighting each other, that both had no legal status, then the Government hoped they could give some justification in selecting a handful of henchmen to represent the Harbour Board workers.

Column: 206



    Sir, at these meetings, the Prime Minister put up a suggestion of electing a Committee and it was turned down. The Union's view was, briefly, that if a negotiating Committee or, for that matter, any other Committee, was going to be elected in the name of the Harbour Board workers to represent them and their Union, then that right of selection must be with the workers and not with the Prime Minister. Sir, it is particularly farcical in a situation like this where the Singapore Government is, in fact, the employer. Sir, no employer in Singapore arrogates to himself the right to appoint a negotiating Committee on behalf of its employees. This is a farce and no trade unionist worth his salt will ever accept such a position. Needless to say, Mr Speaker, if tomorrow every employer follows the example set by the Government, which claims to be pro-labour, which claims to be a model employer, and insists on unilaterally setting up a Committee on behalf of its employees, then there will be chaos and unrest all round.

    Sir, the Union took a strike decision to get the demands met, and the demands were very simple. One, recognition of the Executive Committee. It was pertinent at that moment to have this matter fought out, because if the Union had kept quiet, the Prime Minister would have proceeded to appoint his own Committee. Sir, we know what happened after the workers took a strike decision. The Prime Minister got panicky. The Government got panicky. The Prime Minister, who since 1959 had not gone to the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association to see the Harbour Board workers, who had not gone to the Harbour Board to see the workers, went to the Harbour Board this time. We saw grand pictures in the newspapers of workers shouting pro-Malaysia slogans and greeting the Prime Minister. Sir, here again I would like to take just one moment to say how the facts were distorted. There was no justification for the Government to refuse recognition if the Union and its Executive Committee. They knew that when the workers took a strike decision, they were caught out publicly. To overcome this, the Prime Minister instructed the Harbour Board

Column: 207

to get all the workers together for a meeting. He decided to go direct to the members to get a decision from them. We know that the Harbour Board had a lot of gates. All the gates were locked up. Riot squads and police personnel stood by at the Tanjong Pagar Police Station; plainclothes men filled the Harbour Board area, and Harbour Board personnel were used to go around to force every worker to attend this meeting. The instructions were very simple. "These are working hours. You are an employee of the Harbour Board. The orders are, `You attend this meeting. If you do not attend this meeting, you will be subject to disciplinary action.'"

    At this meeting the Prime Minister announced that he would make this award of a Malaysia bonus. Sir, in the first place, his conduct was very unprincipled, because he had no business to go direct to the workers on an industrial matter that a trade union was representing. In the second place, the State power was used to intimidate and coerce the workers and to get them to see his point of view. There was no fair play. It was all described as a big victory for the Prime Minister. But he had no courage to allow Union officials to address the meeting. The whole exercise carried out by the Prime Minister was to prevent a strike, because if it had taken place, the misdeeds of the Government would have come to public attention. To prevent a strike, he, together with responsible people like Hon Sui Sen, Chairman of the Harbour Board, and other Harbour Board officials, indulged in completely unethical and unprincipled conduct. Even at these two meetings with the Harbour Board workers, we found that they were determined to proceed with their fight to gain recognition; and to prevent this, Sir, with a stroke of the pen, the registration of the Harbour Board Staff Association was cancelled.

    Sir, it is a pity that the Prime Minister is not here. Since he believes in open confrontation, perhaps this would be an appropriate moment to hear what he has to say. But I say that in the Harbour Board dispute it was not the Union which was being political but the Government. The Harbour Board even today, Sir, is

Column: 208

faced with an explosive situation, because the Government wants to play politics with unions and workers. The fact that the Harbour Board Staff Association registration is cancelled by an arbitrary decision of the Government does not resolve the dispute in the Harbour Board.

    The Prime Minister has set up a Committee of six people to try and look after the affairs of the workers. In the first place, Mr Speaker, he has no right whatsoever to appoint such a Committee. In the second place, the appointment of this Committee does not solve the problem. Sir, if a strike takes place, either today, tomorrow, or one week or two months from now, it is not because there are Communists trying to create industrial unrest. Sir, for ten years now the Harbour Board workers have been patient. They were patient when their leaders were arrested. They were patient when their claims were referred arbitrarily to the Arbitration Court. They were patient when their premises were seized. They were patient when $120,000 of their funds was frozen. But they could not be patient any longer when the Government proposed to set up a Committee, a P.A.P. Committee, to represent them in industrial relations. The fact that today the Government have cancelled the registration of the Harbour Board Staff Association only increases the problem. The struggle of the Harbour Board workers continues, and I have no doubt, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the victory will be that of the Harbour Board Staff Association members, and Harbour Board workers as a whole. It is not going to be a personal victory for any individual, be it the Prime Minister or anybody else.

    Sir, the Harbour Board issue is a very clear example of the extent to which the Government is prepared to use State power for its party political interest. Sir, in the past, we have quoted numerous small examples of C. K. Tang, Tiger Breweries, and the Steam Laundries and so on. I do not think I have to repeat all this at this moment. There is no doubt in the minds of the officials of all unions of the intention of the Government. All trade unions, all employers and many people who are one way or the other

Column: 209

connected with industrial problems, industrial relations, know full well that today the Singapore Government's abuse of State power for its political purposes in the trade union field is unprecedented. On the one hand, attempts are made to disrupt the unions which are non-P.A.P., to discriminate against them, to deny them of their fundamental rights and privileges. On the other hand, State power is used to foster the growth of the N.T.U.C. The P.A.P. outfit is led by renegades and discredited leaders in the trade union field. Sir, today, the N.T.U.C. is a big racket. It is supposed to be the P.A.P.'s vehicle for working class support, and it is used to make P.A.P. propaganda to gather support for the P.A.P. amongst the workers. Sir, I have had occasion in the past to say in this House how public funds have been used to assist in the running of this organisation, the Labour Research Unit, $300,000 annually to pay salaries to P.A.P. trade unionists; how the Labour Ministry is being used to pressurise employers into meeting the excessive demands made by this organisation; how the office of the Commissioner for Labour is being used to order secret ballots, to withhold secret ballots in the process of determining union representation, etc.

    Sir, I would like to quote from a letter that appeared in the Malayan Times. I do not have the paper, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have mentioned time and again that if a Member wishes to quote from a newspaper, the newspaper ought to be brought. Which date is that?

    Mr Bani: 23rd of July.

    Mr Speaker: I take it the newspaper must be in the Library. But in future I might be a little stricter.

    Mr Bani: It is a letter in the People's Parliament column in the Malayan Times, 23rd of July. Sir, I quote this letter because the Government has a sickness. Everything we say is branded as Communist propaganda. I think it is worthwhile taking note of what this gentleman has said because, in the first place, I do not think this gentleman is

Column: 210

a Communist by any standards. He starts off by condemning the S.A.T.U. as well. With your permission, Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to read this part because it gives a clear picture of what sort of racket exists in the N.T.U.C.:

    `One of the biggest unions affiliated to the N.T.U.C. is AUPE whose leader is Mr G. Kandasamy. He has been at loggerheads with Mr Devan Nair since the very inception of the N.T.U.C. This resulted in the division of the N.T.U.C. into two factions. Overseas scholarships came in as a handy instrument, which the two groups used to attract promising unionists who, in turn, would help to outdo the other group in their empire building.'

Incidentally, Mr Speaker, this article is entitled "Empire Building":

    `A few months ago when Mr Kandasamy was able to secure a studs course to Israel, sponsored by the ICFTU, he handpicked his adherents from the various unions without reference either to the N.T.U.C. or to the unions concerned.

    On the other hand, the majority group in the N.T.U.C. pampers one or two unions on whose potentialities they have great hopes.

    For instance, let us take the United Workers of Petroleum Industry which represents the employees in oil companies. All the good scholarships, such as study trips to Canada, America, United Kingdom, Germany, and Switzerland are reserved for these pampered chaps. Last year one member from this union went on a Canadian and Continental trip. This year another member, Mr Aziz Karim, has gone on a similar trip abroad. A third one will soon be going to Japan and Vienna.'

In fact, they have since left, Mr Speaker.

    `Members of this union occupy positions in the Adult Education Board and Central Provident Fund Board. These blue-eyed boys are given pride of place in all public functions.

    When the affiliated unions of the N.T.U.C. strained their very nerve to make this year's May Day celebrations a success [which, Sir, was not a success because they had an attendance of only about 3,000], not even the members of the executive committee attended the rally.

    For instance, Mr Aziz, Karim, an official of the United Workers of Petroleum Industry, who was nominated by the N.T.U.C. to work in the Labour Research Unit, had not even shown his face there throughout the last seven months under the pretext of ill-health. It must be noted here that all those unionists, who are seconded to the Labour Research Unit, are paid by the Unit which receives an annual grant of $300,000. For his seven months' absence Mr Aziz Karim has received a grand sum of $3,000 [an average of about $400 a month, Mr Speaker] - the hard-earned taxpayers' money.

Column: 211



    Neither the Director of the Labour Research Unit, nor the Chairman of the N.T.U.C., who is also seconded to the above unit, despite their full knowledge of this, took any action against Mr Aziz Karim.

    This man, who was so indisposed that he absented himself for seven months from his place of work, woke up one fine Monday morning (July 15, 1963) found himself hale and healthy, produced his health certificates at the Singapore Airport, and flew to Canada, leaving a group of unionists stricken with bewilderment.

    This means, in addition to his seven months' absence with pay, he will enjoy another four months with pay in Canada and in the Continent. What a terrible waste of public money!'

Sir, I solemnly swear this is not from a Communist. I only read it from a paper, and it is signed "PRO BONO PUBLICO". But as I have said earlier on, he could not possibly be anybody connected with the S.A.T.U., because there is an initial criticism of S.A.T.U. and its control, etc. [Interruption] Well, you can read it.

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Bani: Sir, I have nothing to hide here. If the Member is quite interested, he can take the Malayan Times and read it in full - five times over in this House - and I will have no objection.

    My point here is to stress the fact that today the Government uses State machinery for its own use, State funds for its own purpose, and forces a few civil servants to carry out work for the advancement of the P.A.P.'s political interests. Sir, this is only one side of it. On the other side, I hear that all is not well even in their unions. I hear that in the Singapore Manual and Mercantile Workers Union, $12,000 is missing, and Mr T. V. Gomez has taken a holiday. I do not know what the Government has done about this. In the Federation of Public Daily-Rated Employees Union, $2,000 is missing. A report was made in the Kandang Kerbau Police Station, but nothing was done. On the other hand, practically every day every union in the S.A.T.U. group is being persecuted by the Registrar of Trade Unions on instructions from the Government. The mess in the Manual and Mercantile Workers Union is known to the workers. If the Government have any decency, I believe they will make a categorical

statement either confirming it or denying it. If they have courage, I say hold a public inquiry and get the Rediffusion workers to testify as to the truth or otherwise of what I have said.
